question: Do you know why I can't do a handstand for more than 10 seconds?
It's not just about strength, but your body's balance, stability and the gravity acting on different parts of your body. It's basically a biomechanics problem!
I just learned to throw a curveball, but I can't figure out why it curves!
Well, it's all about the spin you put on the ball and how air pressure acts differently on each side. You're basically a biomechanics genius now!
I keep tripping in these new high heels. What's going on?
Heels change your body's center of gravity and put more pressure on your toes, which makes walking a bit of a biomechanical challenge!
I just finished mapping out my family tree for the last 300 years.
Oh, so you're into genealogy! But have you considered going a step further with bioinformatics and mapping their genomes?
I heard you're trying to create the perfect playlist for our road trip.
Yes, I'm applying bioinformatics principles. I'm analyzing our music taste patterns and making an algorithm to select the best songs!
I'm struggling with this 1,000-piece puzzle.
Think of it like bioinformatics! Each piece is like a bit of genetic data. You just need to find the right place for it in the big picture.
Can you believe they're growing burgers in labs now?
Absolutely, it's just a new application of tissue engineering. Can't wait for the day they grow pizzas!
I wish I could regrow my hair just like I water my lawn.
We're not too far from that with tissue engineering. Maybe soon, you can grow a lush hair garden!
My dog chewed my favorite shoes. If only I could regrow them.
Well, with tissue engineering we're closer to regrowing organs. Shoes might have to wait a bit longer!
I just swallowed my keys... again.
Don't worry, with today's medical imaging we'll find them in no time!
I'm convinced I have a sixth sense. I think I can see through walls!
Or maybe you've just been spending too much time around the medical imaging equipment...
I thought my heart was on the right.
Medical imaging proves it's on the left. But don't worry, you're right about it being in the right place!
I can't seem to remember anything these days!
Maybe what you need is a biomedical device that beeps every time you forget something.
Look, I can change TV channels with my new smartwatch!
Imagine if biomedical devices could do that, you could control your heart rate!
You know, I've been thinking of getting a new pair of running shoes.
What you need is a pair made from biomaterials, then your feet could help them grow!
I'm thinking of growing a garden on my roof!
Maybe you should look into biomaterials. I hear some can even absorb rainwater!
I wish my clothes would adapt to the weather.
With the right biomaterials, they could. Imagine a shirt that grows fur in winter!
I can't find my glasses anywhere!
Maybe you should get your eyes laser corrected with biomedical optics!
I want to see inside my sandwich to see if there's enough cheese!
Well, biomedical optics could help... if your sandwich was a human body.
I wish I could see what's happening inside my body when I exercise.
With biomedical optics, doctors can look inside without a single incision!
I wish I could change my genes to be taller.
Genomic engineering might make that possible someday, just don't forget to duck under doorways!
Do you think I could genetically engineer a cat that could talk?
Genomic engineering isn't quite there yet, but at least your cat can still give you judgmental looks!
I want to create a fruit that tastes like a burger.
With genomic engineering, maybe we'll get there one day. Burgerberries, anyone?
Imagine if we could control robots with our brains!
That's neural engineering for you, just be careful not to think about dancing when you're operating a bulldozer!
Can neural engineering help me forget my embarrassing moments?
Well, it might be easier to just laugh at them!
I heard neural engineering can help people with paralysis move again.
It's amazing, isn't it? Science is like a superhero, always saving the day!
Cardiovascular engineering, huh? Sounds like heart construction work!
Well, kind of! It's more like designing systems to keep hearts pumping smoothly.
If cardiovascular engineering gets any better, we'll have hearts that never break!
I'm not sure it works on emotional heartbreak, though...
I heard cardiovascular engineering can make artificial hearts. Does that mean I could have a titanium heart?
Maybe, but you'll still need to have a heart of gold!
Rehabilitation Engineering? So, we're rehabbing engineering now?
Nope! It's about designing devices that help people regain lost function, like after an injury.
I heard about rehabilitation engineering. Will it make my grandpa's old radio work again?
Not quite, it’s more about helping humans function better, not radios!
Is rehabilitation engineering like giving a second life to machines?
More like giving a second life to people who need assistive devices!
Biomedical Signal Processing? Is that like traffic signals for cells?
More like interpreting the 'language' of our bodies' electrical signals.
So, Biomedical Signal Processing is like translating alien signals?
If by "alien," you mean the complex signals our body produces, then yes!
Does Biomedical Signal Processing mean I can decode my cat's meows?
Nope, but you could potentially analyze a heartbeat!
Bioinstrumentation? Does that mean I can play the trombone with my brainwaves?
Not quite, it's more about devices that measure biological signals.
I've heard of Bioinstrumentation. Is that like using a stethoscope to listen to my heart?
Yes, that's a simple example! It's all about using instruments to study living organisms.
Bioinstrumentation... Is that like playing the guitar with my heartbeat?
Sounds like a cool concept, but it's more about using technology to monitor and diagnose health conditions.
Pharmacokinetics! Isn't that some sort of magical spell from Harry Potter?
No, it's the study of how drugs move through the body, not a Hogwarts class!
I think pharmacokinetics is about figuring out how fast I can run after taking an energy drink.
Not quite, it's about how drugs are absorbed, distributed, metabolized, and excreted from the body.
I heard pharmacokinetics is all about rollercoasters!
Not the theme park kind, but it does study the 'ride' a drug takes through your body!
Is orthopedic bioengineering about building skeleton forts?
More like designing implants and prosthetics, but skeleton forts do sound fun!
I guess orthopedic bioengineering means I can finally get my rocket-powered legs?
Well, it's more about developing artificial joints and bones, but who knows what the future holds!
So, orthopedic bioengineering is like playing with Legos, but with real bones?
Not quite! It's about designing and improving medical devices for the musculoskeletal system.
